column30: Governor SuperSpreader Now Claims Florida Needs Its Own Army We used to have laws about this kind of thing. By Charles P. PierceDec 3, 2021 There are a number of things with which I would not trust Florida Governor Ron DeSantis. These certainly include the health of his constituents, but that horse has been out of the barn, wheezing its life away for a while now. However, right at the top of the list is the notion that Governor SuperSpreader should have his own private army. From floridapolitics.com: Hoping to distinguish Florida as the most military-friendly state in the nation, Gov. Ron DeSantis rolled out a budget proposal Thursday that would develop new armories and establish a secondary paramilitary force in Florida, among other objectives. A veteran himself, DeSantis is recommending more than $100 million to support the Florida National Guard. The bulk of the funding ‚Äî roughly $85 million ‚Äî would fund the construction of three additional armories, located in Homestead, Gainesville and Malabar, as well as expansion of a readiness center in Miramar. The armories would collectively house more than 1,500 troops, DeSantis said‚Ä¶Unlike the Florida National Guard, the FSG would answer solely to the Governor. No federal deployments. No federal missions. No federal dollars. Also no oversight of any kind. Once, back before the prion disease destroyed the higher functions of the Republican Party‚Äîand American conservatism generally‚Äîthis kind of thing was included in the laws and constitutions of many states. During World War II, for example, the Florida State Guard stepped in when the state‚Äôs National Guard personnel were deployed overseas. Twenty-three states already have state guards that are recognized by the federal government. However, as we have learned repeatedly over the past five years, at least, nothing is normal anymore, not if there is the slightest chance it can be used by Republicans to increase their power. Giving Ron DeSantis his own military at this moment in history is wholly and obviously different than letting ol‚Äô Spessard Holland use the state guard during World War II. This is one reason why. ‚ÄúThis program assists law enforcement efforts to reduce the supply of illegal drugs and will continue to fill an unfortunate void left by the (Joe) Biden administration‚Äôs open border agenda,‚Äù DeSantis said. Also, more than a few people have noticed that DeSantis‚Äôs proposal comes hard on the heels of Secretary of Defense Lloyd Austin‚Äôs directive that National Guardsmen who refuse vaccination will have their pay stopped and be barred from further training. Nobody believes in coincidence any more. It will be interesting to see how many anti-vax soldiers find their way into Ron DeSantis‚Äô private army. Scary, but interesting. Charles P. Pierce Charles P Pierce is the author of four books, most recently Idiot America, and has been a working journalist since 1976. https://www.esquire.com/news-politics/politics/a38424541/ron-desantis-florida-private-army/

column30: New York City expands school vaccination mandate Outgoing NYC Mayor Bill de Blasio has imposed a Covid-19 vaccination mandate on the city‚Äôs private schools, affecting about 56,000 staff. The order is expected to run into resistance from Orthodox Jews. Staff at about 930 Catholic schools, yeshivas and other privately run institutions will have to show proof of at least the first dose by Dec. 20, or risk losing their jobs. Jabs were mandated for public school employees in August. While 77% of all New Yorkers have received at least one jab, vax rates in areas with large Jewish communities, such as Brooklyn‚Äôs Borough Park and South Williamsburg, are 51% and 59%, respectively. One Jewish outlet has already called the order a bad Hanukkah present. The mandate is one of de Blasio‚Äôs last acts in office, as he will be replaced by fellow Democrat Eric Adams on Jan. 1. Adams has already said he would back mandatory vaccinations for students. Subscribe to RT t.me/rtnews

AND that's the FACTS.

column30: Thought for the the day. The TN Assembly is going into a Special Session to consider COVID-related mandates. I wrote the following in ten minutes between shaving and walking my dog this morning. That's how difficult the task is (sarcasm with a smile.) Please read all of this: Here's what we must ALL insist this Assembly accomplish... ...and IF they fall short, hold every single one to account. Political egos and personal comfort of these men and women count for nothing at a time like this. If they can't stand the heat, they can take a piece of paper and a pen and resign from political leadership immediately. It is an election year. The weak can be easily replaced with better men and women. Now for the substance: ‚Ä™The Tennessee Assembly MUST PASS CLEAR LEGISLATION protecting ALL people in TN FROM BEING REQUIRED under any circumstances, by any entities, public or private, to wear COVID-related PPE &/or receive the current COVID vaxs, or any future variant of the COVID vaxs, under penalty of law. The penalties must be stiff and on a per-incident basis. Note - These same Assemblymen AND this Governor enacted LEGISLATION last spring protecting themselves and all government employees at any level from being required to take the COVID vax, ever. Ask them: ‚ÄúWhy didn‚Äôt you protect ALL Tennesseans back then?‚Äù And wait for the excuses to flow. Write it, vote it, get it DONE. EASY‚Ä¨. The Assembly must also write law holding ALL entities in TN which have already required ANY people to receive the vax - in TN - whether TN citizens or not - to provide 100% compensation for all medical care expenses personally incurred for complications arising from the vax. This to include all out of pocket expenses, deductibles, copays, and cash payments made by those who suffered from such vax-related complications. The Assembly must also make law guaranteeing immediate compensation of any next of kin of any Tennessean who died of complications from the vaccine, if required by an employer, in the amount of $350,000 per incident for such death occurring within 365 days of having received a COVID vax, effective from the date such employer made vaccinations mandatory. A little harder, Write it, vote it, get it DONE. EASY‚Ä¨. Legislation must be passed requiring all employers who have terminated employees, or set deadlines for employees to receive the COVID vaccination or be terminated, to provide compensation to former employees, whether they were terminated or chose to resign over receiving the COVID vaccination as a condition of employment, a severance compensation equal to the sum of all wages, tips, salary, and other compensation the employee received in the 365 days preceding the employee's last paid day of work. Such amounts to be paid in equal installments over the next twelve months, beginning January 1, 2022. Write it, vote on it, get it DONE. Easy. If I can do this before coffee in the morning, why the hell can't the legislators do it? Bob Hendry #BobTheRinoHunter

column30: This study is interesting, but everyone needs to assume control of their own health in consultation with a trusted medical provider. An issue I have with this study is that it compares adverse vaccine reactions to adverse risks with the virus--without breaking down the controllable risk factors of the infected. The word ""safe"" is thrown around indiscriminately based on those concerns. We all do not have the same susceptibility to a significant bout with this virus; conversely many who have gambled on those lines have had a severe infection. A spokesman with Baylor Waxahachie has stated that 92-94 percent of their serious COVID-19 admissions are unvaxxed, That seems to agree with what other local hospitals are experiencing. . I took the Johnson and Johnson vaccine on April Fool's Day. Insert your sarcasm here, if needed. I have had short-term and controllable hives several times since. Inconvenient, but not a severe problem. I also have used some alternative and inexpensive medications when I thought I might have been exposed with no reaction. It turned out I was not infected. Converse with a doctor who pays attention to your concerns. I have taken all of the recommended supplements to avoid the virus such as D-3, Quercetin, Zinc, and Magnesium. I have taken them in meaningful doses. ""DrBeen"" on YouTube discusses these on his broadcasts and discusses them with a global network of Doctors and PhD-level researchers. Most of these folks are to some degree pro-vax and some are pro-mask in some circumstances, but they discuss alternatives to expensive therapies as well.

column30: Alex Jones threatens to 'dish all the dirt' on Trump Former President Donald Trump's recent comments touting COVID-19 vaccines have roiled extreme anti-vaxxers, including many of his ardent supporters. 'I no longer can support him' üòÇü§£üòÇü§£üòÇü§£ Former Republican President Donald Trump's recent comments touting COVID-19 vaccines as safe and a major achievement of his presidency have roiled extreme anti-vaxers, which include many of his ardent supporters. After months of a relatively low profile on vaccines and no photos of him getting inoculated, Trump on Dec. 19 told former Fox News host Bill O'Reilly during an event in Dallas that he'd received the booster - eliciting some boos from the audience. In an interview with right-wing pundit Candace Owens released two days later, Trump pushed back when Owens suggested the shots were not safe. ""Oh no, the vaccine works,"" Trump interrupted Owens, who said she was not vaccinated. ""The ones that get very sick and go to the hospital are the ones that don't take the vaccine."" While in both cases Trump stressed that he is against Democratic President Joe Biden's vaccine mandates, his comments have stoked rare criticism from anti-vaccine activists and some supporters. The controversy highlights the balancing act Trump might face in a potential 2024 presidential run: He will have to energize his base, for many of whom opposition to vaccines has become a rallying cry, without repelling moderate suburbanites. Conspiracy theorist and radio host Alex Jones said on his talk show that by touting the vaccine, Trump was either ""completely ignorant"" or ""one of the most evil men who has ever lived."" He said it was time ""to move on"" from Trump and also threatened to ""dish all the dirt"" on the former president. Radio host Wayne Allyn Root, a staunch Trump supporter, said the former president was ""right on everything"" except the vaccines, and needed an ""intervention."" In a statement to Reuters, Root stressed he would always be a Trump supporter and that by ""intervention"" he simply meant a chance to convince Trump to ""alter"" his message. A spokesperson told Reuters that Trump stands by his administration's ""tremendous contributions to ending this pandemic"". There was no immediate reply to requests for comments from representatives for Jones or Owens. On right-wing social media groups, some Trump voters argued that he is acting strategically to keep hostile media at bay. Others, however, professed dismay. ""I no longer can support him,"" Daniel McLean, 42, who works in the cannabis industry in Oregon, said in an interview. McLean said he had steadily grown disappointed with what he views as Trump's embrace of the political establishment. The pro-vaccine comments were a tipping point, added McLean, who said he was not inoculated and repeated debunked theories about thousands of people dying from the shots. Republicans and Republican-leaning independents now account for 60% of unvaccinated adult Americans, according to a Kaiser Family Foundation analysis. That makes Trump's comments all the more surprising, said Republican Martin Hyde, who is running as a challenger to Florida Congressman Vern Buchanan in the 2022 elections. ""I don't think that's a message which will resonate with the base,"" Hyde told Reuters. GRUMBLING AND GRIPING? Trump continues to have a near-iron grip on Republican voters. Candidates in the 2022 midterm elections are vying for his endorsements; he is the clear favorite for the 2024 presidential race; and he is preparing to launch a social media site that has reportedly entered into agreements to raise about $1 billion. ""I'm with Trump all the way,"" wrote a user under the name Crockett on a Telegram app chat about Trump's vaccine comments. ""Trump knows things we don't."" There is no polling yet to ascertain whether Trump's vaccine comments have hurt his standing with the base. Nicholas Valentino, a professor specializing in political psychology at the University of Michigan, said it is unlikely to create a serious rift. ""The more extreme faction in this group doesn't have anywhere else to go politically,"" said Valentino. McLean in Oregon, for instance, said he still prefers Trump over Biden. Georgia Congresswoman Marjorie Taylor Greene, a key Trump ally, on Monday appeared to try to smooth over the issue, urging supporters to focus on COVID-19 originating in China. ""We should be holding those who made the virus accountable, not fighting one another,"" she said on Twitter. Still, Ron Filipkowski, a former federal prosecutor and Trump critic who monitors the extreme right, said Trump going out of his way to tout the vaccines has sent ""shockwaves"" through his base. ""A year ago, you would never hear any dissent whatsoever among them,"" said Filipkowski. ""Now you're at least hearing the grumbling and the griping. And that's definitely new."" (Reporting by Alexandra Ulmer; Editing by Dan Grebler and Daniel Wallis)

column30: This is an insightful, scriptural view. Please read it.
column34: This is a re-share of a post
column35:
The Pastor of a church in Georgia that I listen to and respect gave a message today on the topic of vaccines and masks, and he rightly (in my view) used Romans 14 as the appropriate Scripture reference. He does NOT take a position one way or the other on vaccines or masks and that was not the point of his message. His advice was to read the Bible. Pray about it. Do your own research on vaccines and masks. You can watch the message below.

Vaccines of course are not addressed in Scripture one way or the other. They are NOT a doctrinal issue and I believe it is a mistake to try to make them one. Paul covers such matters in Romans 14. In Paul's day, the issue was meat sacrificed to idols. There are many such issues today and in so many cases, individuals and Christian, myself included, resort to legalism in an attempt to force others to adopt what is their belief not what is Biblical.

Article after article and comment after comment on this issue resort to bashing and attempting to shame others into wearing a mask or getting a vaccine. First, that is NOT Scriptural. It is also not helpful if your goal is to convince people that your view is right.

As the Pastor in that sermon pointed out we should not divide over this issue. We should look at it through Romans 14. That means we should also not be bashing those that disagree which sadly happens all the time. We should not be judging others. He gave an example from both sides on how ridiculous some of the claims have been including one I have often seen which is ""those who have not been vaccinated, don't care about others."" 

Ad hominem attacks are common on this issue in both articles and comments that appear on social media. Does anyone believe such attacks help your cause? Are some of you mind readers who know the mind of the unvaccinated? Do you believe your attacks are Scriptural? They aren't. Just to be clear, ad hominem attacks are wrong no matter who is guilty of them. The vaccine hesitant and those opposed to vaccines are also guilty of them. 

Do those who attack the unvaccinated ever think about how it is you who wants to force a vaccine into everyone when YOU can't possibly know if those vaccines will have adverse side effects? Do YOU know the individual circumstances of each individual? No, you don't So is that being loving? No, it isn't. Attacking those that have received one of the vaccines isn't loving or Scriptural either. I have seen many such attacks on social media,  from memes to comments, that are wrong coming from Christians,,  or anyone in my opinion.

When even the real experts have changed their views many times over such matters as new information becomes available what makes you think you know ALL the science? You don't.

So on the matter of vaccines and masks we need to treat it in light of Romans 14. Give grace to those who disagree. Try not to divide over such matters. Don't try to make vaccines one way or other as being Biblical. If you do you might be a legalist.

I do not tell anyone to get or not get a vaccine. I am not anti-vax. I want to make that clear, so those who might pass along my comments who are opposed to all vaccines should know that is NOT my position. I am anti-mandate. 

I urge every Christian to watch the message which is linked below and consider what Pastor Clark says. If you agree or disagree, we all need to quit the bashing and shaming of those we disagree with. That is not Scriptural.

column30: This is a letter sent today to our legislators from https://www.kshf.org. The whole idea of testing being the ultimate in knowing how to go forward is deeply flawed at best. Taking time to research the tests KDHE wants to use on us, requires diligent research just like researching the vax and meds they want to use on us. Again, as Americans, where there is risk there must be choice. ""Since so much weight is being put on testing, testing, testing, we thought it wise to do a bit of research on where our Kansas test kits are coming from and their track record for accuracy. We were able to obtain, through FOIA requests, copies of a Purchase Invoice and Purchase Order (attached) for 500,000 test kits used in Kansas. These documents show these kits were purchased from OKEC, LLC (a Delaware LLC), with shipment coming from Shanghai China to Topeka, Kansas. Recent news has pointed to some serious concerns regarding the accuracy of test kits coming out of China: ‚ÄúCoronavirus testing in the UK has been delayed after kits were found to be contaminated with Covid-19, it's reported.‚Äù (1) ‚ÄúSome 80% of coronavirus rapid tests China donated to the Czech Republic as part of the communist country‚Äôs global goodwill effort are faulty, according to news reports.‚Äù (2) Tanzania president questions testing - ‚ÄúTest kits were faulty as they had returned positive results on a goat and a pawpaw [an indiginous fruit] ‚Äî among several non-human samples submitted for testing, with technicians left deliberately unaware of their origins.‚Äù (3) Georgia man tests positive, then negative, four hours apart. (4) In addition to the concerns over inaccuracy of these tests, we also investigated how PCR tests work and their limitations. Read these quotes from this article, ‚ÄúFlaws in Coronavirus Pandemic Theory‚Äù by David Crowe. (5) ‚ÄúThe COVID-19 test is based on PCR, a DNA manufacturing technique. When used as a test it does not produce a positive/negative result, but simply the number of cycles required to detect sufficient material to beat the arbitrary cutoff between positive and negative.‚Äù (pgs. 1-2) ‚ÄúGiven that several people bounced back from negative to positive again, one could argue that the cutoff should be more (or maybe less) than 37 cycles. But likely if this was done many more people might test positive, and even with a cutoff of, say, 40, going to negative and back again might still occur.‚Äù (pg. 15) ‚ÄúSome test results simply do not make sense if the test accurately reflects an infection that comes, making someone positive, and then goes, returning the person to negative. Often, when ‚Äòimpossible‚Äô test results occur, authorities tie themselves in knots trying to explain the test without questioning the accuracy of the RT-PCR RNA test for COVID-19 or the viral paradigm.‚Äù (pg. 40) The FDA‚Äôs instructions on PCR testing (6) include using 40 cycles (see page 34). It appears that the results from these PCR tests can return a different result, depending on how many ‚Äúcycles‚Äù are used. Here is another document put out by Monterey County, California: ‚ÄúPCR Testing: Advantages, Limitations and Interpreting Results‚Äù which states that ‚ÄúPCR testing alone may be limited as a diagnostic tool.‚Äù (7) As you can see, while PCR tests may be a good start for testing, they can be very inaccurate and therefore should not be used to diagnose. Also considering they are coming from China, which is under some scrutiny surrounding their involvement in the leak and spread of this virus, it should give us pause to rely too heavily on this test for diagnosis.""

The shipping of and storing of hazardous pathogens is haphazard. 2. There is a conflict of interest, if not a breach of security when a scientist working on DARPA also works with China. 3. The biosafety level 4 (BSL-4) lab in Wuhan is the only such lab in all of China. Conceived in 2003 and completed in 2015. However, Corona-virus related projects were in process years before it's official completion date. 4. ""Dr. George Church, Professor of Genetics at Harvard Medical School and Professor of Health Sciences and Technology at Harvard and MIT"" is a colleague of Dr. Lieber. 5. Most recently in his career, Dr. Church has been funded by DARPA and IARPA, with the most recently funded grant titled, ‚ÄòFunctional Genomic and Computational Assessment of Threats‚Äô (by IARPA)."" 6. At the time, he was also working with researchers at Harvard. 7. Rep. Chip Roy (R-TX) on Monday blasted Democrats who want to police private text messages, following a report that Biden allies want to use SMS carriers to dispel misinformation about the COVID-19 vaccine. Roy appeared on ‚ÄúTucker Carlson Tonight‚Äù in part to address a Monday report from Politico that claimed the Biden administration is ‚Äúcasting conservative opponents of its Covid-19 vaccine campaign as dangerous and extreme‚Äù and plans to work with SMS carriers to suppress anti-vaccine sentiment even in private texts. As Carlson said, per Fox News: On Monday, Politico reported plans from the Biden administration to battle misinformation in regards to the COVID-19 vaccine. ‚ÄúThe White House has decided to hit back harder on misinformation and scare tactics after Republican lawmakers and conservative activists pledged to fight the administration‚Äôs stated plans to go ‚Äòdoor-to-door‚Äô to increase vaccination rates,‚Äù Politico wrote. ‚ÄúThe pushback will include directly calling out social media platforms and conservative news shows that promote such tactics.‚Äù The article continues how pro-Biden groups and the Democratic National Committee will work with SMS carriers to ‚Äúdispel misinformation‚Äù in peoples‚Äô private text messages. ‚ÄúBiden allied groups, including the Democratic National Committee, are also planning to engage fact-checkers more aggressively and work with SMS carriers to dispel misinformation about vaccines that is sent over social media and text messages,‚Äù Politico reports. Describing the DNC‚Äôs alleged tactics to interfere with private text messages as ‚Äúpatently absurd,‚Äù Roy said, ‚ÄúThis whole issue of the vaccine hits very close to home for me. My father, in 1949 when he was seven years old, he was diagnosed with polio. And my grandmother was nursing my grandfather, who was sick with cancer ‚Äî he died that fall ‚Äî and then raised my dad as a single mom, nursed him to health. And he lived his whole life ravaged by it. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm grateful to have a vaccine for me, vaccines for my sons and my daughter,‚Äù Roy continued. ‚ÄúI believe in vaccines, and I‚Äôll be damned if I‚Äôm going to allow Democrats ‚Ä¶ come in and start calling you an anti-vax quack or call me an anti-vaxxer because I dare to believe that it is our duty as Americans, our patriotic duty, to make decisions for ourselves, not have Democrats looking at our text messages, not having them try to shame the American people into taking a vaccine.‚Äù ‚ÄúThis is the danger we face as Americans, the forgotten men and women out here who are getting rolled over by the power of government, but also the oligopoly, these corporate cronies who are trying to use all of this to fatten their own wallets,‚Äù Roy added. Roy spoke out last week against the Biden administration for aggressively pushing COVID-19 vaccines, prompting a White House official to reportedly scoff at his concerns. As The Daily Wire reported: A White House official reportedly dismissed concerns Rep. Chip Roy (R-TX) made this week regarding the Biden administration‚Äôs recent move to go door-to-door pushing the COVID-19 vaccine. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm just sick and God-darn tired of the Left, and this government, dictating to me, frankly, anything at all,‚Äù Roy told RealClearPolitics White House reporter Philip Wegmann in an interview. ‚ÄúBack the F off. That‚Äôs my message to the White House.‚Äù When Wegmann reached out to a White House official to ask if they had a response to Roy, the official texted, ‚Äúlol no.‚Äù

column30: Harry‚Äôs Bar Randt 9-17-21 To Jab or not to Jab. That is the question. Here‚Äôs Harry‚Äôs unedited take. O.K. Now, about 175 million people in the US have been fully vaxed for the lung flu. As of September 13th: ‚ÄúMore than 380 million doses of COVID-19 vaccines were administered in the United States from December 14, 2020, through September 13, 2021. During this time, VAERS received 7,653 reports of death (0.0020%) among people who received a COVID-19 vaccine.‚Äù (CDC website fat checker) Breakthrough cases are rising steadily, and estimates are that soon we‚Äôll be seeing 35,000 breakthrough cases per week. I don‚Äôt necessarily believe that, but it‚Äôs out there. (CDC website fat checker) So . . . almost 90% of those vaxed who subsequently died were people over 65, and of THOSE over 55% were males. (CDC website fat checker) If that many vaxed people are still gonna get sick from the thing and the majority of the deaths will be men over 65 and I‚Äôm 54, where‚Äôs the logic in my taking the jab? At my age and with my history of drinking and cigar smoking for 40 years, a bout of influenza could wipe me out. Figured I already have neurological damage, not in the mood to suffer a long drawn death on a ventilator like I‚Äôve seen so many over the last year suffer, I‚Äôve had a good run, tried to help out when and where I could, never deliberately hurt anyone who didn‚Äôt deserve some hurtin, and believe my record will stand up in any accounting in an afterlife by a reasonable judge. So I said Saddle up, what‚Äôs the big deal if I let them pop in some shit that for the most part will result in pain and loss of income for a day or two. And that‚Äôs what happened minus the loss of income. Only had a fever for a few hours. That‚Äôs was it. But is it? nah that‚Äôs not it. See while I‚Äôm not an anti vax person I‚Äôm a big anti Gummint mandate person. I took mine back in May and did it of my own free will and for a few more reasons then those mentioned. Hard to believe, but I remember when I was a kid teachers didn‚Äôt like me for the simple reason I always asked, ‚ÄúWHY.‚Äù Those in the pissition of authority hate being questioned. Seems suits behind a podium telling us to take an untested subdued RNA injection that could result in pain, loss of facility, neurological damage, or lingering death so that a bunch of greedy politicians can just get richer and we ask WHY they seem to take issue with it. They call those who question them, extremist, conspiracy theorist, right wing lunatics and so on. I figure they wouldn‚Äôt like me that much either. My friend Ruthie had a good post that summed up questions: ‚ÄúWe no longer use asbestos because brave people questioned ‚Äòthe science‚Äô Doctors no longer recommend cigarettes because brave people questioned ‚Äòthe science‚Äô *DDT is no longer sprayed on people because brave people questioned ‚Äòthe science‚Äô Pregnant women no longer take thalidomide because brave people questioned ‚Äòthe science‚Äô Mercury is not used as a cure, and we understand it now as a toxin because brave people questioned ‚Äòthe science‚Äô Billions of lives saved by simple hand washing pre-surgery because a brave doctor called Ignasz Semmelweis questioned ‚Äòthe science‚Äô, was put in an asylum and humiliated At some point, the people questioning ‚Äòthe science‚Äô were ridiculed and shunned. They would have been censored. They would have been ignored, ridiculed, shamed and worse. But that‚Äôs how science works. By questioning and finding and researching and observing and yes, sometimes ‚Äòthe science‚Äô is wrong and has to be changed based on evidence. All of the practices listed above with the exemption of * DDT which may have been found less harmful then first thought ( still there are many more examples) were believed to be safe and effective. They were only stopped when enough people questioned them and the evidence honestly and bravely investigated. Questioning the science is not wrong, disrespectful or stupid. It is the intelligent, mature and moral thing to do when you notice something is amiss. It is science itself!‚Äù Like most reasonably intelligent adults, I don‚Äôt believe ANY of the shit stats the government provides through any of its agencies, especially the CDC and NIH. They‚Äôve lied so often about so much and changed their stories so frequently that it‚Äôs hard to take them seriously. As of about 10 days ago, the total number of US cases was reported to be 40,900,000 with 660,000 deaths. That‚Äôs a mortality rate of 1.6%, and I‚Äôm convinced that many of those deaths were complex situations involving obesity, asthma, bronchitis, diabetes, and so on. An aquantence of mine recently died in his mid-70s of complications from age-related Parkinson‚Äôs. What was the official cause? You guesses it, the hospital tagged it ‚Äúcovid-related.‚Äù The US population is around 330,000,000, so somewhere around 220 million have been jabbed or got the stuff and now have natural immunity, and I‚Äôm not including those who had it but didn‚Äôt know it, which could very well be a sizeable (truncated)

Those that stood against segregation and for our Charter Rights should consider this a massive victory. Please share ASAP, as this will not be allowed in most FB groups.

column30: FRI. & THE WHEELS ON THE GOP BUS GO ROUND & ROUND REPUKES DEFEND THE INDEFENSIBLE ANTI-VAX LOGIC THINKERS DEMAND THAT VACCINES & MASKS BE MANDATED Source: All articles appear in their entirety in Raw Story dated 8/20/21. Comment: My friends have all checked in for the start of the early weekend. The reason is simple, they follow the CDC guidelines, they are vaccinated, wear a mask, and stay at least six feet away from a-holes aka Anit-Vaxxers. Another week completed and the wheels on the bus go round and round, and the anit-vaxxers will never get off and get vaccinated. These troglodytes would rather continue spreading the virus, and use our nation as if it is a roulette wheel, in a game of chance called life or death. The Grand Hypocrisy Party where 90% or more of thiose that preside in the either Chambers of Congress have their familes and themselves vaccinated, say one thing and do another, and their stated ideology is completely intellectually inconsistent and filled with hypocrisy. They serve up their garbage like is was coffee to their uneducated, gullible, racist anti-vaxxers. The Fascist Republican lawmakers are constantly espousing unscientific propaganda to their Stupids, who are too dumb to realize that they are more susceptible to dying, then their hated enemies the Thinking Vaccinated Citizen. On the odd chance that an Anti-Vaxxer comes upon my article, and the pictures grab their attention, I leave few bits of scientific information from Web MD. and the CDC is regards to COVID-19. HOW CONTAGIOUS IS THE CORONAVIRUS? INFO AS OF 12/18/20 The transmission rate is relatively high. Early research has estimated that one person who has it can spread it to between 2 and 3.5 others. One study found that the rate was higher, with one case spreading to between 4.7 and 6.6 other people. By comparison, one person who has the seasonal flu will pass it to between 1.1 and 2.3 others. The CDC reports there is evidence it can be transmitted if you get within 6 feet of someone who is infectious for a total of 15 minutes throughout a day. It had previously been believed the exposure had to be 15 minutes at a time. We can work to lower the transmission rate by wearing cloth face masks when we can‚Äôt stay 6 feet away from others, washing handsoften, keeping common surfaces clean, limiting contact with other people, and getting vaccinated. Can a face mask protect you from infection? The CDC recommends that if you are not vaccinated, you should wear a cloth face mask if you go out in public. If you are at home with someone who has been infected or exposed, you should wear it as well. A mask is an added layer of protection for everyone, on top of social distancing efforts. You can spread the virus when you talk or cough, even if you don‚Äôt know that you have it or if you aren‚Äôt showing signs of infection. The CDC advises that surgical masks and N95 masks should be reserved for health care workers and first responders. HOW CAN YOU HELP STOP THE SPREAD OF THE CORONAVIRUS Because the virus spreads from person to person, it‚Äôs important to limit your contact with other people as much as possible. and avoid large gatherings. Many states and cities have eased restrictions but this doesn‚Äôt mean the virus is gone. Continue to follow safety practices such as wearing a cloth face mask in public places and washing your hands. GOP ABANDONS CORE IDEAS TO SCORE POINTS ON COVID On Friday, writing for The Atlantic, columnist David Graham criticized Republicans for rejecting their party's central principle of ""freedom"" to crack down on businesses that make personal decisions to impose science-based restrictions for COVID-19. One of the key governors pushing this contradiction, noted Graham, is Gov. Greg Abbott (R-TX). ""The pandemic has given Abbott new avenues to push for freedoms. Abbott has, for example, barred state agencies and organizations that receive state funding from requiring vaccines for consumers,"" wrote Graham. ""The public-health wisdom of this position is dubious, but it is consistent with the idea of limiting government restraints. What's confusing is a bill that Abbott signed in June, which bans businesses from requiring custom ers to be vaccinated. With rising concern about, and case counts from, the Delta variant, the state Alcoholic Beverage Commission issued a warning on August 12 declaring that restaurants and bars that ask customers to show proof of vaccination might have their liquor licenses revoked."" Many Republicans have of course chosen to focus on restricting local governments from imposing mandates, like Gov. Ron DeSantis (R-FL) threatening to strip pay from superintendents who impose mask mandates, and Gov. Doug Ducey (R-AZ) trying to offer incentives to schools to not require masks in a possibly unlawful scheme. But Abbott's move is something altogether different, wrote Graham. TX. column30: Our Napolean in the White House has disturbed a political hornets' nest. October 11, 2021 Southwest Airlines forced to cancel 1800+ weekend flights one day after pilots‚Äô union filed for a restraining order on vaccine mandate By Thomas Lifson Top Articles By American Thinker It doesn‚Äôt take Sherlock Holmes to figure out that pilots at Southwest Airlines are protesting their company‚Äôs move to require Covid vaccinations, even though the company and their own union deny it. Over the past weekend, Southwest was forced to cancel over 1800 flights: The Dallas-based carrier canceled over 1,000 flights Sunday and 808 flights Saturday equivalent to 27 per cent of its entire schedule for the day, over the Columbus Day holiday weekend. Prior to the arrival of Covid, Southwest was the largest carrier of passengers in the United States. I don‚Äôt know if that is still the case because the pace of recovery of airline operations has been uneven. But undeniably, Southwest is a major presence in domestic air travel. Southwest is the only carrier so massively affected by cancellations. On Sunday, American Airlines also canceled two per cent of its flights while Spirit Airlines axed two per cent of theirs, according to FlightAware. From Twitter via the UKDM Last Friday, the pilots‚Äô union at Southwest filed for a restraining order preventing the company from enforcing a vaccine mandate, as has already been enforced at United, American Alaska, and Jet Blue Airlines. However, the union president is denying that its pilots are walking off the job to protest the forced participation in an experimental genetic therapy. The president of the Southwest Airlines Pilots Association (SWAPA) blamed the flight woes on staffing and a ‚Äúpoorly run operation.‚Äù This, however, appears to be eyewash, a safeguard against being accused of an illegal work stoppage. Alex Berenson received a communication from a Southwest pilot explaining: The pilot emailed following the first Southwest post today (and provided his SWA ID to prove his identity). He asked that I paraphrase the email. Essentially, the union cannot organize or even acknowledge the sickout, because doing so would make it an illegal job action. Years ago, Southwest and its pilots had a rough negotiation, and the union would not even let the pilots internally discuss the possibility of working-to-rule (which would have slowed Southwest to a crawl). But at the moment the pilots don‚Äôt even have to talk to each other about what they‚Äôre doing. The anger internally - not just among pilots but other Southwest workers - is enormous. The tough prior negotiations notwithstanding, Southwest has a history of decent labor relations, and workers believe the company should stand up for them against the mandate. Telling pilots in particular to comply or face termination has backfired. ‚Äî Meanwhile, Southwest has more flexibility than it has acknowledged. Federal contracts represent about 3 percent of its revenue, but even the Biden administration CANNOT alter existing contracts (please note, I have not checked this, though it seems reasonable); Southwest is only at risk of losing future contracts. Another instance of air traffic disruption, attributed by some to the vax mandates but officially denied, took place at the Jacksonville Air Traffic Control Center. News4JAX: The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) blamed widespread flight cancellations this weekend on bad weather and air traffic control issues in Jacksonville. The FAA on Sunday afternoon said the flight delays and cancellations occurred for a few hours Friday evening due to widespread severe weather, military training and ‚Äúlimited staffing in one area of the Jacksonville en route center.‚Äù (snip) News4Jax asked the FAA and called the Air Traffic Control center in Hilliard asking if the vaccination mandate has anything to do with these delays, but we haven‚Äôt heard back. (snip) Both the FAA and Southwest Airlines pointed to problems or limited staffing at the Air Traffic Control Centers. Airline pilots have more leverage than most workers because it takes so long to train them. Most ‚Äì some estimate 80% of Southwest‚Äôs pilots ‚Äì come out of the military. That‚Äôs why former military and commercial pilot and Congressional candidate Buzz Patterson was contemptuous of a suggestion that replacements could be found:‚Äô Sundance points to the larger issue at stake: [T]his is not about vaccines per se‚Äô, this is more about a slippery slope of having the government dictate how you can live your life and earn a living. If they can force you to have a medical procedure, and then carry documentation of that procedure in order to work‚Ä¶ why can‚Äôt they force you to get a small electronic implant of your identification, which would coincidentally include your medical authorizations for work? It‚Äôs just a metal detector‚Ä¶. it‚Äôs just taking off your shoes‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs just wearing a mask‚Ä¶. it‚Äôs just a vaccination‚Ä¶.. it‚Äôs just a COVID passport‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs always, ‚Äújust‚Äù. He (truncated)

column30: Democrat Governor Whitmer...No Extralegal Political Methods Shall Be Required. The polling booth on election day is all that's necessary. September 23, 2021 Michigan's Gov. Whitmer bans masks and vax mandates as her polls crash and re-election fight looks grim By Thomas Lifson Gretchen Whitmer, the governor of Michigan, early on distinguished herself as a pandemic hypocrite, demanding severe lockdowns of her citizens subjects while exempting her family and herself. Her husband was caught boating when she had forbidden ordinary Michiganders to do the same, and she was caught traveling to Florida, violating her own proclamations. Resentment has grown, and not even an FBI informant‚Äìled bogus kidnapping plot has been enough to keep her polls strong as she faces re-election in November 2022. Mary Chastain of Legal Insurrection spotted Whitmer signing legislation that specifically banned the state from enforcing mask mandates and vaccine passports: Whitmer and the Michigan state legislature agreed on a budget. This is no ordinary budget because it bans mask mandates and vaccine passports: Democratic Michigan Gov. Gretchen Whitmer and the state legislature have agreed on a budget proposal that includes language banning health officials from enforcing mask mandates in schools and preventing state public agencies from enforcing vaccines on employees or customers. ""The director or local health officer shall not issue or enforce any orders or other directives that require an individual in this state who is under the age of 18 to wear a face mask or face covering,"" the 1,000-page budget states in one section. Chastain notes that school districts are still free to enforce mask mandates. The reason for Whitmer's reversal is not hard to figure out. Her polls stink. The Hill reports on a Trafalgar Group poll that shows her six points behind former Detroit police chief James Craig (who notably kept the peace there as Minneapolis and other cities were burning): Michigan Gov. Gretchen Whitmer (D) trails former Detroit Police Chief James Craig by 6 points in a hypothetical general election match-up, according to a poll released this week. The survey from the GOP-leaning Trafalgar Group shows Craig, a Republican, leading Whitmer 50.4 percent to 44.4 percent among likely general election voters. Another 5.2 percent of respondents remain undecided. Craig, who retired as Detroit police chief in June after nearly eight years on the job, announced his campaign for governor earlier this month at the urging of top Michigan Republicans. Trafalgar may be right-leaning, but other polls also indicate trouble. The Detroit News: Gov. Gretchen Whitmer's job approval has fallen to a point where Michigan voters are nearly split about how she is doing, according to a new poll released Monday, marking a large decline from prior surveys. The decrease has occurred as the Aug. 31-Sept. 3 survey by the Glengariff Group found that a majority of 600 registered voters said the state is on the wrong track and that they disapprove by a wide margin of the job that President Joe Biden is doing. About 48% of voters approve of the Democratic governor's performance and 46% disapprove, according to the poll commissioned by the Detroit Regional Chamber, whose political action committee in 2018 endorsed Whitmer over Republican Bill Schuette for governor. The latest numbers are a marked shift from September 2020, when 59% of voters approved of Whitmer's performance and 38% disapproved (snip) Much of Whitmer's approval decline has occurred among independent voters, 39% of whom approved of her performance and 51% of whom disapproved, according to the poll, which has a margin of error of plus or minus four percentage points. ""Michigan elections are decided by independent voters and how she does with these independent voters moving forward will really dictate"" her performance in the 2022 election, said Richard Czuba, a pollster with the Lansing-based Glengariff Group. It looks as though, worldwide, resentment and rebellion against lockdowns and other severe restrictions are on the rise. The fact that so many politicians exempt themselves and their families from the masking and other restrictions they place on those they regard as inferiors isn't helping.

SINE DIE (Latin for ""we're quitting"" now, no matter what)

The Texas Legislature could not find the energy to fix SB1 from the last special session that reduced the penalty for election fraud from a felony to a misdemeanor, or ban employer vax mandates. 

For those who have been told that the election fraud change was an error that slid through, it seems clear that this change was deliberate. See the pic, a screen shot from House Speaker Dade Phelan's Twitter account. Note his statement: ""After two quorum breaks by a number of House Democrats, this important legislation made its way through the House after several thoughtful amendments were adopted."" 

I must admit that I do not understand why this could be considered thoughtful. Can anyone elaborate, or are we to just think the worst? 

Of course, the legislature did finally act on the ""boys in girls' sports"" issue and did get the district lines drawn, but as always...it just seems like we are always dropping the ball and making everything harder than it should be. 

Fourth Special Session, anyone?

column30: I firmly believe vaccines should be a choice. If you believe a vaccination keeps you safe from a virus, feel free to get it. If you're mad that I, and many others, will refuse that vaccine then you dont really believe your vaccine works. Simply put on the petition, ""Individuals have rights to self-determine about their health, body and life. Therefore, no one, much less the government should interfere with the individual‚Äôs right to undergo or abandon medical treatment. Medical decisions for children should be left to parents or guardians."" The government cannot force treatment on someone with AIDS, and they can walk around forever invisibly infectious. Govt cannot force treatment on someone with terminal cancer, and they can take the risk of it killing them. Govt cannot force someone to take the antivenom if they're determined to risk fighting the futile battle of overcoming a fatal snakebite. The Govt cannot force someone to have their gangrenous foot amputated if they want to suffer through it falling off. It is not acceptable for the government to force people who are sick to seek treatment (let alone demanding it be the ONLY choice offered for treatment like a vaccine would be). It can't simultaneously be logical to force preventive treatment on someone healthy to treat the virus they haven't or may never come down with. ‚òÜif you sign the petition, DONT FORGET TO VERIFY your signature by clicking the link they send you by email.‚òÜ Before the comment is even thought up, I'll address it. NO, I am not anti-vax. I believe there are many types of vaccines that have been a blessing for humanity (like the measles vax. So consistent that a vaccination from 1960 could work just as effectively today as then). I believe that vaccines for quickly mutating viruses like influenza are the equivalent of Russian FLUlette; you might be lucky and it contains the strain going around (in the grab bag of strains chosen for that seasons flu shot), but then again the gun might end up being full of blanks. I shouldn't feel the need to say this, yet again, but I will. I am not an expert in any field. I am not telling anyone not to get the vaccine when there is one available. That's actually the whole point, I'm not telling anyone how I think they should be made to address their health. If you think people aren't capable of making adult decisions, you are simply projecting your own shortcomings onto the general population, and you are free to relinquish your right to make that choice. DO NOT make it my obligation to hand over rights just because you did. I'm sure there are plenty of things you treasure that I consider to be as ridiculous and meaningless as you decided my rights are.

column30: COPIED FROM ANOTHER POST: An open letter to the Prime Minister. Hey ScoMo, I just wanted to let you know that I‚Äôm already participating in your vaccine roll out with great results! ‚Äì More about that later. I know there‚Äôs a few pesky ‚Äúanti-vaxers‚Äù out there, but you won‚Äôt have to worry about them till the next election, although their numbers are growing from what I can see. What I‚Äôm observing is that many of the people who the pollies and the media like to label as anti-vaxers and conspiracy theorists in order to belittle, them are actually intelligent, thinking people who have had multiple vaccinations throughout their life and done their research. They are not anti-vax. They are against an experimental vaccine, with no demonstrable benefits and they know that it hasn‚Äôt been tested properly. Anyway, I digress‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm so glad the first shipment of va c c in es has landed and that your mates at the TGA have given 2 pharmaceutical concoctions provisional approval under the recently rushed through EUA ‚Äì Emergency Use Approval system which only requires limited testing. It must have been quite difficult for them to go through the rigorous rubber-stamping process you told us about. It‚Äôs interesting that as part of the TGA‚Äôs rigorous safety checking, regulator and now media star in your misleading advertising campaign, John Skerritt provided labelling exemptions to Pfizer on 13th January 2021 including the removal of a warning ‚ÄúKEEP OUT OF THE REACH OF CHILDREN‚Äù and this labelling exemption was given about a month before the Pfizer medicine was even provisionally approved by the TGA. To an ordinary bloke like me this seems a bit odd, but of course Professor John has been on TV telling us all what a thorough job he and his fellow rubber stampers at the TGA have been doing, so we should all have a warm fuzzy feeling in our undies. I guess it must be because this concoction of genetically modified organisms, chimpanzee adenovirus and embryonic kidney cells is perfectly safe for everyone who wants this stuff in their body, including unsuspecting children. I guess the fact that there are so many people in our regulatory agencies and government who have links to the pharmaceutical industry, the world economic forum and the billionaires makes it a lot easier to get things done these days. I know you are a pragmatist and would like that sort of thing even though your pesky constituents might think it a conflict of interest. But, never mind Scotty, it‚Äôs probably just a conspiracy theory. Most people are just amazed that the pharmaceutical companies were able to get the v a cci ne s out to market in such a record time. I guess they just wanted us all to be safe, sooner. I never knew companies were so benevolent. Thanks also for personally assuring us that the va cc in e s are completely safe. We know we can absolutely trust you because of your extensive medical knowledge and training. I understand that your Health Minister Greg Hunt has precisely the same medical qualifications as you, however what‚Äôs comforting for us to know is that he previously worked as Head of Strategy at the World Economic Forum. That‚Äôs the organisation promoting The Great Reset where we will in future own nothing and be happy. But you already know that because you are carrying out their agenda, even though Klaus Schwab‚Äôs pontifications are quite opposite to Liberal Party values and beliefs. I‚Äôm sure the Australian People are so glad we‚Äôre in such safe hands and that you have our best interests at heart. Perhaps the Liberal Party should be renamed the LINO Party ‚Äì Liberal In Name Only. And of course, the cheeseburger eating and coke drinking medical expert and philanthropist geek with the same medical qualifications as you and Greg, has been urging us all to be vaccinated as well. I know he‚Äôs not interested in the massive profits he‚Äôs going to make from all the va cc in e$ produced by companies that he‚Äôs heavily invested in. That‚Äôs probably just another conspiracy theory isn‚Äôt it Scomo? You‚Äôve demonstrated your complete support for the Australian people by making your mates in the pharmaceutical industry completely immune from prosecution for any side effects from the v @ c ci ne $ which you are urging us all to take even though you can‚Äôt tell us what the benefit of doing so will be. Not even the Australian Government will provide any compensation to the victims of v@ cc in e injury so we as the Australian people can clearly see your complete faith in the safety of this v A cc in E roll out. You‚Äôve told us that even after we‚Äôve been vaccinated, ‚Ä¢ We may still catch the virus ‚Ä¢ We may still pass it on to others ‚Ä¢ We can‚Äôt be sure it will work against future strains of the virus ‚Ä¢ We may need to be re j@bb E D because the v@cc in e will only work for a short time ‚Ä¢ You don‚Äôt know effective the V @ cc I n e $ will be ‚Ä¢ We‚Äôll still have to social distance and won‚Äôt be able to hug our loved ones ‚Ä¢ We‚Äôll still have to wear masks And the ‚Äúexperts‚Äù (truncated)

column30: Delete if not allowed This was a conversation with a ""Mental Health Professional"" regarding a man who was left to die after being thrown off the transplant list. This man here, mocked and ridiculed that guy who refused to Vax, and when I opposed his tactics, he began to slander me with false mental health diagnosis, because my opinion, and my questioning of his obviously false statistics were in opposition to his ""science"" this is supposed to be the PRESIDENT of a mental health facility in Eugene OR. Welcome to the Nazi doctors of today. Obey my science or die as a mentally ill lunatic for not believing the narrative and ""Vaccinating"" Besides the obvious errors in the statistics he provides, this guy has decided that you deserve to die if you don't submit to your loss of freedom by not vaccinating.

This is for you my one family member who doesnt want to vax, this is for you my one close friend who has done their research.... I'm vaccinated and, no, I don't know what's in it - neither this vaccine, the ones I had as a child, nor in the Big Mac, or in hot dogs, or in other treatments‚Ä¶whether it's for cancer, AIDS, the one for polyarthritis, or vaccines for infants or children. I trust my doctor when he says it‚Äôs needed. I also don't know what's in Ibuprofen, Tylenol, or other meds, it just cures my headaches & my pains ... I don't know what's in the ink for tattoos or every ingredient in my soap or shampoo or even deodorants. I don‚Äôt know the long term effect of cell phone use or whether or not that restaurant I just ate at REALLY used clean foods and washed their hands. In short ... There's a lot of things I don't know and never will‚Ä¶ I just know one thing: life is short, very short, and I still want to do something other than just going to work every day or staying locked in my home. I still want to travel and hug people without fear and find a little feeling of life ""before"". As a child and as an adult I've been vaccinated for mumps, measles, rubella, polio, chicken pox, and quite a few others; my parents and I trusted the science and never had to suffer through or transmit any of said diseases . I'm vaccinated, not to please the government but: * To not die from Covid-19. * To NOT clutter a hospital bed if I get sick. * To hug my loved ones * To Not have to do PCR or antigenic tests to go out dancing, go to a restaurant, go on holidays and many more things to come ... * To live my life. * To have my family's and friend's kids/grandkids go back to school and play sports. * For Covid-19 to be an old memory. * To protect us. Text copied, you can too. 1 Comment Mack Butler I agree.

When confronted with problems that could easily be alleviated through cooperative action, the radical right-wingers who have taken over the Republican Party often turn instead to bizarre nonsolutions that appeal to their antisocial ideology. Guns, Germs, Bitcoin and the Antisocial Right Jan. 31, 2022 In February 2021 a deep freeze caused widespread power outages in Texas, leaving about 10 million Texans without electricity, in many cases for days. Hundreds died. The biggest proximate cause of the crisis was disrupted production of natural gas, the state‚Äôs most important power source. After a 2011 freeze, federal regulators had urged Texas to require winterization of gas and electricity facilities. But it didn‚Äôt. And for the most part it still hasn‚Äôt: So far, no winterization requirements have been placed on the politically powerful gas sector. Instead, Gov. Greg Abbott is hoping to secure the power grid by encouraging ‚Ä¶ Bitcoin mining. This would supposedly reduce the risk of outages because Bitcoin‚Äôs huge electricity consumption would eventually expand the state‚Äôs generation capacity. Yes, that‚Äôs as crazy as it sounds. But it fits a pattern. When confronted with problems that could easily be alleviated through cooperative action, the radical right-wingers who have taken over the Republican Party often turn instead to bizarre nonsolutions that appeal to their antisocial ideology. I‚Äôll explain why I use that word in a minute. First, let‚Äôs talk about the most obvious current example: Covid policy. In Florida, Gov. Ron DeSantis has tried to block just about every measure intended to limit the spread of the coronavirus; he and his officials have stopped just short of being explicitly anti-vaccine, but they have catered to the anti-vax fringe, with DeSantis even refusing to say whether he has received a booster shot. They have, however, gone all in on antibody treatments that are far more expensive than vaccines, with DeSantis demanding that the Food and Drug Administration allow use of antibodies that, the F.D.A. has found, don‚Äôt work against Omicron. Why support expensive, ineffective treatments while opposing measures that would help prevent severe illness in the first place? Well, consider a parallel that may not be immediately obvious but is actually quite close: school shootings. Among major advanced nations, such shootings are an almost uniquely U.S. phenomenon. And while there may be multiple reasons America leads the world in massacres of schoolkids, we could surely mitigate the horror with common-sense measures like restrictions on gun sales, required background checks and a ban on privately owned assault weapons. But no. Republicans want to expand access to guns and, in many states, protect students by arming schoolteachers. What do these examples have in common? As Thomas Hobbes could have told you, human beings can only flourish, can only avoid a state of nature in which lives are ‚Äúnasty, brutish and short,‚Äù if they participate in a ‚Äúcommonwealth‚Äù ‚Äî a society in which government takes on much of the responsibility for making life secure. Thus, we have law enforcement precisely so individuals don‚Äôt have to go around armed to protect themselves against other people‚Äôs violence. Public health policy, if you think about it, reflects the same principle. Individuals can and should take responsibility for their own health, when they can; but the nature of infectious disease means that there is an essential role for collective action, whether it is public investment in clean water supplies or, yes, mask and vaccine mandates during a pandemic. And you don‚Äôt have to be a socialist to recognize the need for regulation to maintain the reliability of essential aspects of the economy like electricity supply and the monetary system. Which is why I‚Äôm calling the modern American right antisocial ‚Äî because its members reject any policy that relies on social cooperation, and they want us to return instead to Hobbes‚Äôs dystopian state of nature. We won‚Äôt try to keep guns out of the hands of potential mass murderers; instead, we‚Äôll rely on teacher-vigilantes to gun them down once the shooting has already started. We won‚Äôt try to limit the spread of infectious diseases; instead, we‚Äôll tell people to take drugs that are expensive, ineffective or both after they‚Äôve already gotten sick. What about Bitcoin? I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs even worth trying to make sense of Abbott‚Äôs tortured logic, why he imagines that promoting an environmentally destructive, energy-hogging industry will somehow make his state‚Äôs electricity supply more reliable. (An energy grid overloaded by crypto mining helped set off the recent crisis in Kazakhstan.) A better question is why Republicans have become fanatics about cryptocurrency, to the extent that one Senate candidate has defined his position as being ‚Äúpro-God, pro-family, pro-Bitcoin.‚Äù The answer, I‚Äôd argue, is that Bitcoin plays into a fantasy of self-sufficient individualism, of (truncated)

column30: The Supreme Court Just Spit in the Face of Joe Biden and the American Public When the Supreme Court blocked OSHA‚Äôs vaccine-or-test mandate on Thursday while upholding the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services‚Äô vaccine requirement for all health workers, you might think this was a split decision with the justices just calling balls and strikes. You‚Äôd be dead wrong. This was a hyper-partisan decision that will eviscerate President Biden‚Äôs COVID-19 strategy. First let‚Äôs discuss just how hypocritical the six conservative justices are. The court insists on some of the strictest COVID-19 policy rules in the nation. All attorneys must take a PCR test and wear N95 or KN95 masks in court. But what they demand for themselves they deny to a construction or assembly worker. In other words, the most privileged can protect themselves, but they would deny that protection to everyday workers. The Supreme Court‚Äôs decision will directly result in thousands of preventable deaths. We‚Äôve been stuck at a vaccination rate of just over 60 percent, and far lower for boosters. That places us near the bottom of our peer nations. The president‚Äôs only shot at boosting vaccination coverage was his large business mandate, which would have reached 85 million workers. By comparison, the CMS mandate is small change because most health workers are already vaccinated and large hospitals already require it. OSHA itself estimated its rule would save the lives of 6,500 workers, but that doesn‚Äôt factor in the lives of family members and others that a mandate would also have protected. The disastrous ruling will hit especially hard in red states where governors are fiercely opposed to mandates. States like Florida, Texas, and Arkansas actually ban employers from requiring vaccinations, even if employers think it‚Äôs a smart business decision, which it is. And the OSHA rule would have provided political cover to business leaders worried about facing a public and political backlash. It also would have preempted anti-vax state laws. Let‚Äôs examine the court‚Äôs reasoning. The justices were clearly hostile from the start about big, bold federal regulation. They kept calling OSHA‚Äôs rule a vaccine mandate, which it isn‚Äôt. Employees can simply be tested and masked‚Äîa really basic workplace safety strategy, and hardly an overreach. The justices also were hostile to the idea that OSHA could set any safety rules for COVID-19. After all, the pandemic affects all parts of society and isn‚Äôt unique to the workplace. That‚Äôs true but it ignores two fundamental legal issues. First, Congress explicitly granted OSHA the power to regulate workplace safety hazards and didn‚Äôt insist that those hazards apply exclusively to the workplace. If the court were just calling balls and strikes, they would be faithful to the text of the Occupational Safety and Health Act. Second, COVID-19 does create a unique workplace risk. There‚Äôs no other place where people spend eight hours a day crowded together with strangers‚Äînot in grocery stores, restaurants, or even concerts. And here‚Äôs the thing: Most Americans have no choice but to earn a living. They deserve to work in a healthy and safe environment. The justices made a big deal out of the fact that OSHA‚Äôs rule would have huge economic impacts in the private sector. But OSHA has set countless rules that incur major costs on employers. The vaccine-or-test mandate is hardly unique in that regard, and it would have applied only to large businesses while most OSHA rules apply to all businesses. The court went headstrong into the so-called ‚Äúmajor questions‚Äù doctrine, which casts major doubt on any regulatory action that has large political or economic impacts. If Congress were not allowed to delegate major powers to regulatory agencies, it would unravel not just what OSHA does, but also CDC, FDA, and EPA. It places at risk federal protection against dangerous consumer products, unsafe food and drugs, and nuclear or chemical hazards, just to name a few. As Justices Breyer, Sotomayor, and Kagan said in dissent, the OSHA rule is indeed far-reaching. But it reflects the scope of the crisis‚Äîa health emergency unprecedented in the nation‚Äôs history, having killed more than 800,000 Americans to date, with a new variant so infectious that it poses grave risks in shared indoor spaces that are the hallmark of American working life. Never before has a health emergency been so politically divisive. And never before has a president had to contend with a majority of justices so ideologically bent on blocking commonsense health and safety regulations.

column30: Biden‚Äôs Private Sector Vax Mandate Begins Jan 4 ‚Äì with $136K Penalty for Wilful Non-Compliance The mandate applies to businesses with 100 or more employees ‚Äì about 84mn people officials said. Employers will need to show all workers are fully vaccinated by Jan 4 or adopt policies that allow unvaxxed workers to submit to weekly testing and mask-wearing. Penalties for non-compliance can range from $13,653 per serious violation to $136,532 if a company wilfully violates the rules. AUGUST 2021: ‚Äú***Russian Disinformation Targets Vaccines and the Biden Administration*** A new campaign appears to be spreading falsehoods about the potential for forced inoculations against Covid-19.‚Äù New York Times Aug. 5, 2021 ‚ÄúIt is difficult to quantify the amount of disinformation being produced at any time by the Russians or other adversarial powers, government officials and outside experts said. But the [rise of the Delta variant of the coronavirus](https://www.nytimes.com/2021/07/30/health/covid-cdc-delta-masks.html) ‚Äî and shifting scientific advice on how to defend against a more infectious strain and the need for booster shots or masks ‚Äî has created an atmosphere for misinformation to more easily spread, experts said. ‚ÄúDisinformation thrives in an information vacuum,‚Äù said Lisa Kaplan, the chief executive of the Alethea Group, which helps corporations guard against misinformation. ‚ÄúThat is when disinformation can really take hold. And knowing how the Russians typically play those situations, it wouldn‚Äôt surprise me they are trying to take advantage of it.‚Äù The aim of various Russian groups continues to be to exacerbate tensions in Western societies, a key foreign policy goal of Moscow, according to American officials briefed on the disinformation efforts.‚Äù CRIMINALLY NEGLIGENT GOP ARE WILLING TO ENDANGER AMERICANS TO CONTROL CONGRESS: CONTRARY TO THE LEADER OF THE REPUBLICAN PARTY‚ÄôS PRO-VACCINE STANCE, DIRTY-LOW LOWEST-COMMON BOTTOM-BARREL BAD-BATCH CONGRESSIONAL REPUBLICANS SPENT THE BEGINNING OF THE BIDEN PRESIDENCY SPEWING COVID DISINFORMATION AND ATTACKING DOCTOR FAUCI. THEIR CONTRIBUTION TO THE SURGE THAT RESULTED IN THE PROLONGED PRESENCE OF THE PANDEMIC MUST NOT BE FORGOTTEN DURING MIDTERM MADNESS, SINCE ILLNESS, DEATH, AND AN ATTEMPT TO HAMPER A RECORD-BREAKING ECONOMY ARE TRAITOROUS NATIONAL SECURITY VIOLATIONS. ‚ÄúAs you can see, Trump said that ‚Äúthe vaccine is one of the greatest achievements of mankind.‚Äù Trump, surprise, surprise, took credit for the vaccine by saying, ‚ÄúI came up with a vaccine, with three vaccines.‚Äù He used the words ‚Äúcame up with‚Äù even though Trump was probably not one of the many scientists working in the laboratories or clinics on the vaccines. ‚ÄúAll are very, very good,‚Äù he added. ‚ÄúCame up with three of them in less than nine months. It was supposed to take five to 12 years.‚Äù Of course, real science doesn‚Äôt work as Tony Stark and Iron Man do. No one can come up with a completely new vaccine technology in under nine months. Trump didn‚Äôt give birth to the vaccine after carrying it for that just that long. Instead, researchers had worked on mRNA vaccines for over a decade. The U.S. was lucky, darn lucky, that this technology happened to be available to be used against the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2). Nevertheless, Owens interrupted Trump‚Äôs praising of the vaccine and himself with ‚ÄúYet more people have died under COVID this year. By the way, under Joe Biden, than under you and more people took the vaccine this year. So people are questioning how‚Äî.‚Äù Whomp. Did Owens just throw a ‚ÄúJoe Biden‚Äù into the conversation? Nonetheless, Trump stayed on point and syringe, interrupting back by emphasizing, ‚ÄúOh no, the vaccines work, but some people aren‚Äôt the ones.‚Äù He continued with, ‚ÄúThe ones who get very sick and go to the hospital are the ones that don‚Äôt take the vaccine. But it‚Äôs still their choice. And if you take the vaccine, you‚Äôre protected.‚Äù Trump added, ‚ÄúLook, the results of the vaccine are very good, and if you do get it, it‚Äôs a very minor form. People aren‚Äôt dying when they take the vaccine.‚Äù Trump for the most part was correct. The vaccine doesn‚Äôt offer 100% protection though. It‚Äôs not like a gigantic full-body concrete condom. You can still get very sick with Covid-19 if you are vaccinated, albeit your chances are much, much lower. That‚Äôs why combining other Covid-19 precautions such as face mask wearing and social distancing are so important as long as the SARS-CoV-2 is still spreading in a relatively uncontrolled manner.‚Äù https://www.forbes.com/sites/brucelee/2021/12/24/trump-tells-candace-owens-that-covid-19-vaccines-work-one-of-the-greatest-achievements-of-mankind/?sh=44eecaff434f

column30: The Plane Truth about Vax Tyranny November 16, 2021 Tony Perkins What air travel needs right now is more restrictions, said 37 Democratic lawmakers in a letter to President Biden, saying, ""as the nation approaches holiday season, we ask that you put in place requirements for airline passengers to provide proof of full vaccination against COVID or a negative test to board a domestic flight."" Their call for further travel restrictions doesn't just unhappily coincide with the holiday travel season; they explicitly cite that as a reason to enact the restrictions. These would-be scrooges should have asked the airlines. Just as retailers and other businesses who survive on December sales begged the Biden administration to postpone the employer vaccine mandate until January, so airlines ""have come out months ago and said that they were opposed to"" the travel mandate,"" said Congressman Garret Graves (R-La.). Businesses live in the real world, where they must respond to market forces if they want to survive. Therefore, they recognize (far more than D.C. politicians) that most Americans who haven't gotten vaccinated don't appear to be changing their minds, regardless of the carrots and sticks the federal government wields. ""Many Americans remain reluctant to spending [sic] extended periods of time in enclosed public spaces due to the risk of COVID-19 exposure,"" continues the letter. Assuming that's true, whose fault is that? Graves, a member of the Transportation and Infrastructure Committee, said top researchers have testified before Congress ""that airline travel is safe, that they effectively had not found any cases of where transmission happened on an airplane."" Air cabin ventilation entirely recycles the air within seconds; any infected air doesn't linger long enough to infect anyone else. But the Democrats' claim is more a symptom of their ""Forever Covidism"" than an accurate reflection of what Americans are thinking. COVID is no longer the foremost issue in voters' minds, as the 2021 elections and recent polls have shown. In fact, there are probably more Americans ""reluctant to spend extended periods of time in enclosed public spaces"" because they're required to wear a mask regardless of vaccination status. Let's face it; Democrats are simply pulling power levers for the fun of it. The Democrats who wrote this letter didn't do it because Americans are too scared to fly. They did it to punish the unvaccinated, so they can't see their families for the holidays without jumping through extra hoops to show proof of a negative test. Just like the U.S. Navy is withholding promotions and pay from the .5 percent of unvaccinated, active-duty sailors. All for a virus with an over 98 percent survival rate. Speaking of tests, Graves warned that if we suddenly start requiring all unvaccinated Americans to get tested before doing things like flying, we ""probably don't even have the capacity to do the testing quickly."" That will add travel delays on top of those that will be created by vaccine mandates on air traffic controllers, TSA employees, and airline staff. Which creates more travel headaches: a chronically understaffed airport, or one in which a small percentage of staff aren't fully vaccinated? ""You think you've seen bad holiday travel conditions? You just wait,"" warned Graves. ""Forever Covidism"" is now a far more dangerous pandemic than COVID. Its symptoms include unchecked government tyranny, punishing people for personal medical decisions, needless fearmongering, hampering early childhood development and education, exacerbating depression and addictions, destroying livelihoods, and separating families. That's far worse, for most Americans, than contracting COVID. There is cure available for Forever Covidism ‚Äì it's called freedom ‚Äì but we must use it!

column30: Federal Appeals Court Affirms Hold on Biden's Divisive Vax Mandate Friday, 12 November 2021 07:32 PM A U.S. appeals court on Friday upheld its decision to put on hold an order by President Joe Biden for companies with 100 workers or more to require COVID-19 vaccines, rejecting a challenge by his administration. A three-member panel of the 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in New Orleans affirmed its ruling despite the Biden administration's position that halting implementation of the vaccine mandate could lead to dozens or even hundreds of deaths. ""The mandate is staggeringly overbroad,"" the opinion said. ""The mandate is a one-size-fits-all sledgehammer that makes hardly any attempt to account for differences in workplaces (and workers),"" Circuit Court Judge Kurt Engelhardt wrote for the panel. Vaccine mandates are deeply controversial in the United States. Supporters say they are a must to put an end to the nearly two-year coronavirus pandemic, while opponents argue they violate the U.S. Constitution and curb individual liberty. They also say the mandate threatens to diminish a workforce already grappling with labor shortfalls and major kinks in supply chains. The Fifth Circuit judges appeared to agree with the opponents. ""The public interest is also served by maintaining our constitutional structure and maintaining the liberty of individuals to make intensely personal decisions according to their own convictions - even, or perhaps particularly, when those decisions frustrate government officials,"" Engelhardt wrote. The rule was issued by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) and mandates that businesses with at least 100 employees require staff to get vaccinated or face weekly tests and face mask requirements. White House officials had no immediate comment on the ruling, which was hailed as a victory by Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton. Texas joined other U.S. states, as well as private employers and religious organizations, in legal challenges to the order. ""Citing Texas‚Äôs 'compelling argument' the 5th Circuit has stayed OSHA‚Äôs unconstitutional and illegal private-business vaccine mandate,"" Paxton said on Twitter. Biden imposed the requirement in September, telling Americans that ""our patience is wearing thin"" with those refusing to get inoculated.

No surprise for NB, who actually got as far as proposing vax passports for buying groceries.] ‚ÄúNew Brunswick is the latest Maritime province to announce plans to remove all COVID-19 restrictions and guidelines. ‚ÄúPremier Blaine Higgs said all pandemic-related restrictions and mandates will be eliminated at 12:01 a.m. on March 14. ‚ÄúAt that time, all mandatory orders will be lifted, which means masks won‚Äôt be required indoors or outdoors, capacity limits will be eliminated and physical distancing requirements will be no more, along with isolation requirements for the general public. ‚ÄúEffective 12:01 a.m. Monday, proof of vaccination will no longer be required at facilities such as gyms, entertainment centres, churches and restaurants. ‚ÄúOther measures under Level 1, including masking and physical distancing, will remain in effect until March 14. ‚ÄúA mandate that requires government employees to be vaccinated against COVID-19 was put into effect, which resulted in some workers being laid off after they refused the order. ‚ÄúHiggs said, as the province looks at pandemic policies, vaccine mandates are also being reviewed for existing employees. He says vaccine mandates will remain for any new employees.‚Äù

column30: Trudeau and Biden‚Äôs mandates for truckers target an industry that transports 70 percent of goods between their two countries, and as the Biden federal mandate for private employers was halted by the Supreme Court last week, an industry with already low vaccination rates is unlikely to increase the roughly 50-60 percent of truckers who have gotten the jab. How many workers will be affected by disruptions caused by these mandates? It‚Äôs not just the truckers, it‚Äôs the workers in all the other industries that rely upon transport to do their business, as well as the consumers. Bloomberg‚Äôs Jen Skerritt noted last week that Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau is playing a ‚Äúdangerous game‚Äù by blocking unvaccinated American truckers from entering his country as this makes thousands of drivers ineligible to transport goods into Canada. We‚Äôre talking about potentially millions of people whose livelihoods and economic stability are going to be threatened because Trudeau and Biden want to require truckers to get vaccinated ‚Äî the same truckers who made sure that goods were transported at the peak of the pandemic when no one was vaccinated.
